title: Powering down on energy politics
text:
“We naturally want to keep evolving and improving the fund,” he says, totally dismissing any suggestion it’s because the government is not confident of meeting its Paris commitment. This is for a 26-28 per cent reduction in emissions on 2005 levels – a target the government has repeatedly insisted “will be met in a canter” and years ahead of the deadline.

This is meant to counter persistent criticism, including from much of the energy industry, that Canberra lacks a coherent energy and emissions reduction strategy.

The Emissions Reduction Fund has so far paid for 190 million tonnes of carbon abatement at a cost of $15 a tonne or less but now has less than $250 million left of the original $2.55 billion allocated.

King, a former chief executive of Origin Energy as well as the retiring president of the Business Council, says the successful bids have largely come from the agricultural and land use sectors rather than industry, energy or transport.

“We want to broaden the engagement and accelerate the rate at which reduction occurs,” he tells The Australian Financial Review. “We have received around 40 submissions so far.”

Investing in reliability

The panel is one of several measures taken by the Morrison government as part of what it is calling “A Fair Deal on Energy”. Beyond the Utopia-style title, this is meant to counter persistent criticism, including from much of the energy industry, that Canberra lacks a coherent energy and emissions reduction strategy.

The government also announced on Wednesday an additional $1 billion for the Clean Energy Finance Corporation to back projects to help stabilise and support the power grid. This is part of its plan to back investment in “firming” power permanently available to ensure the energy system remains stable as well as reliable when the generation of wind and solar power is low or non-existent.

Advertisement

“It is no secret that the National Electricity Market is under pressure,” Taylor says. “This fund is designed to tackle that and is part of a suite of initiatives that the government is delivering to ensure when people flick the switch, the lights come on and stay on.”

The new CEFC-administered “grid reliability fund” will centralise the government’s financial support for new generation and storage from sources such as batteries, pumped hydro and gas, as well as some of the investment needed to upgrade transmission networks.

But the money is primarily designed to provide a form of a banking facility or guarantee designed to unlock additional private sector investment, mainly by underwriting new dispatchable generation projects.

This includes underwriting most of the 12 projects the government has already shortlisted for federal backing, although it is still negotiating the details of this with the individual companies selected. All involve pumped hydro or gas projects in Victoria, NSW, South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland with the one exception of the upgrade of a coal-fired power station in NSW.

Turnbull: 'a one out of two'

This upgrade will now be supported via a different mechanism given the mandate – not to mention the name – of the Clean Energy Finance Corporation. But the original vision for the CEFC has been largely rendered redundant by the extraordinary growth in wind and solar power since its establishment by the Labor government. That was to bolster innovation and investment in renewable energy given what was then a fledgling commercial industry.

The corporation had not received any new capital since 2012.

Advertisement

As prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull quickly rejected the failed attempt by Tony Abbott to abolish the CEFC. Turnbull was even quicker to respond to the Morrison government’s latest contribution, praising it on Twitter as a “good move” while saying it was “worth recalling” his predecessor’s view.

Not that Turnbull is reconciled to his successor’s approach to emissions reduction either, grading the government's effort as a one out of two.

A key factor to ensure the fund’s success, he says, will be “zero emissions electricity, deliverable by renewables plus storage including pumped hydro” and “electrification of the economy esp[sic] transport, heating, cooling” and with "more transmission vital".

Turnbull was the prime minister who came up with the massive and massively expensive pumped hydro project of Snowy 2.0, of course. And despite welcoming recent announcements, Turnbull maintains – unsurprisingly – that much more is still needed.

The Morrison government is certainly aware of the need to demonstrate it is meeting that need. Its website proudly details the three pillars of its “energy policy blueprint” – reliable, secure and affordable supply; putting consumers first and meeting our international commitments.

It is confident disruptive climate change protests like those against a Melbourne mining conference this week will only consolidate broader community support for its more moderate approach to climate change targets relative to Labor. But that still requires demonstrating the government can deliver both lower prices and lower emissions. September quarter inflation figures showing a 0.7 per cent reduction in electricity prices won’t be nearly enough.
description: The Morrison government is determined to counter the persistent criticism that it lacks a coherent energy and emissions reduction strategy.
